fields.body:
Hace poco me enteré que Manuel García lanzó un nuevo album. He aquí un video clip (que añejo suena eso) de una de las canciones que compone su último disco. Pero antes, una frase que recalco.

 

♪ Tu eres la reina que dejo su rey por un alfil. Por que el café lo tomas junto a mi ♫

 

 

Bien AM el sonido del tema.
fields.title: Lo nuevo de Manuel García

fields.body:
Sometimes I need make a mini-simply-fast django project which do something. In this post show how to make something like that. Basically the idea is to put the views and the urls in the settings.py and voilá.

 

import os
from django.conf.urls.defaults import patterns
from django.http import HttpResponse
filepath, extension = os.path.splitext(__file__)
ROOT_URLCONF = os.path.basename(filepath)

def yoohoo(request):
    return HttpResponse('Yoohoo!')

urlpatterns = patterns('', (r'^hello/$', yoohoo))

 

In the original post exist more information about this.
fields.title: mini simply fast django project

fields.body:
The past week I was lucky to go see the Dave Matthews Band in SantiagoCL. It was awesome, one of the top 5 moments in my life :). I was at 15-20 meters away of them.

 

My favorite song (see my last.fm profile) belongs to DMB, #41 is a classic of the classics. I can't add anything else. Obviously, in my favorite song I have a favorite part (obviously!) and it is:

 

♪ I wanted to stay

I wanted to play,

I wanted to love you ♪


This verse expresses what I feel in any moment. I simply love this song. There is a special feeling when the song start with the hi-hat and the guitar. It's a musical orgarsm for me! :P
fields.title: A little tribute for my favorite song

fields.body:
Ayer terminé de ver The Girl Who Leapt Through Time en donde aparece la frase Time waits for no one. Lo anterior me ha hecho pensar mucho en lo poco que he hecho y avanzado por las cosas que quiero en mi vida. Me apresura y presiona el pensar que ya llevo una fracción importante de mi vida, en donde aprendes de la misma y vas decidiendo que quieres para el final de ella. Ahora me siento en la etapa en que vas por las metas y (ojalá) las cumples y siento que llevo un 0.1%.

Lamentablemente casi nada es fácil. Pero de hecho a mi no me importa lo difícil que sean las cosas y etapas, sino lo dolorosa y terribles que puedan llegar a ser. Hace poco he vivido un terremoto grado un millón en mi vida, una tragedia (en mi escala de medición) en donde todo o la gran mayoría de lo que tenía se desplomó. Y la tristeza asociada a tal terrbile evento no va por el lado de que se hayan destruído sino del como ocurrió, de lo herido que quedé, de la gran oportunidad que se perdió, además de la nula posibilidad de que haya otra igual.
fields.title: Time waits for no one

fields.body: With a painfull title. Ryan Farish, and his theme Letting Go. This is the theme of the day/week/month/year and so on until the infinity.
fields.title: This is a beautiful song

fields.body:
When I was making statistic online (February 2010), I was searching for a javascript library for statistics charts: histograms, boxplot, scatterplot, time series plot, etc... But none of them had a histogram and boxplot chart (then statistics-online.info  does not support this type of graphics). Finally in the past week I found the Hamilton Ulmer's page. He developed a javascript library which can make this type of charts (you can see his demos here). However, in the boxplot you'll need give the min, max and quantiles as parameters, and not the "vector of data". But this is better, and really better than nothing. 

 

 

 

 

Hamilton did a great job :).
fields.title: Histogram & Boxplot js library

fields.body: Time ago in my old blog I had a last.fm widget to show my recent scrobble songs. And I dont no why I deleted it. In this site show the necesary script to put the (flash) widget again. I don't like a lot flash, but this widget is nice than an image! rigth?
fields.title: I found the lost last.fm widget

fields.body:
Some time ago I needed a simple script to display my twitter status on my blog whitout using the Twitter API. Today in django-es@googlegroups.com I saw  this link.

The code is:

 

from django.template import Library
import urllib
from django.utils import simplejson

register = Library()

#This is in the original line of code
#@register.simple_tag 
# I use the next line instead of the other
@register.filter 
def twitter_status( username ):
    url = "http://twitter.com/statuses/user_timeline/%s.json?count=1" % username
    file  = urllib.urlopen(url)
    json_response = file.read()
    try:
       twit = simplejson.loads(json_response)
       msg = twit[0]["text"]
    except :
       msg = " ..."	
    return "%s" % msg

 

It's ultra-simple and work :). Thanks to Zodman.
fields.title: Django and Twitter without API
